node.title: How Hispanics Became Swing Voters
node.description: Republicans see an opportunity. Democrats have a lot of work to do.
node.content: ["The chart that should frighten Democratic strategists appears in the 23rd slide of a newly released report from Equis Research, which tries to explain the Hispanic shift toward the Republican Party in the 2020 election. It shows how favorably Hispanic voters responded to a variety of Donald Trump\u2019s positions and policies, on Covid and the economy and immigration \u2014 more favorably, in many cases, than many liberals would have expected.", "Some responses aren\u2019t all that surprising: 77 percent favorability for pandemic stimulus, 74 percent favorability for \u201crapid vaccine development,\u201d 69 percent for middle-class tax cuts (who could be against middle-class tax cuts?). Some of them offer interesting evidence that Trump\u2019s Covid insouciance, his attempt to prioritize economic reopening over precaution, was popular with Hispanic voters: \u201creopen economy\u201d at 66 percent, \u201cCovid policy set by states\u201d at 62 percent, \u201cliving without fear of Covid\u201d at 55 percent.", "But it\u2019s the numbers on immigration and border policy that are particularly notable. Trump\u2019s family-separation policy, not surprisingly, polls at 28 percent. But \u201cmore border spending\u201d gets 55 percent approval, \u201climiting refugees/asylum\u201d receives 51 percent and even \u201creducing legal immigration\u201d gets 49 percent.", "At the same time, \u201cmore deportations\u201d and \u201cbuild the wall\u201d poll lower, at 42 percent and 39 percent. But then recall that Trump got only 38 percent of the Hispanic vote overall. Which means that in an important sense, despite overperforming expectations, he arguably underperformed his potential with Hispanics. He didn\u2019t even consolidate the full share of voters who favored building his border wall, let alone the share that supported other forms of immigration restriction, let alone the share that agreed with his Covid response.", "Or as the report puts it, \u201cAbsent any context, the numbers might even suggest that the incumbent should have done better than he did.\u201d", "This is just one survey, but it\u2019s congruent with a lot of different data sources suggesting that Trump\u2019s improvement with Hispanics in 2020, rather than an outlier that other Republicans won\u2019t hit, represents a foundation on which the G.O.P. could potentially build further gains. Ruy Teixeira, the analyst whose famous \u201cemerging Democratic majority\u201d thesis (shared with John Judis) was welcomed and then misinterpreted by Democrats banking on the inevitable march of demographic change, has been particularly aggressive in warning about this scenario. In a recent post, he rattled off several polling results suggesting that Republicans could be moving close to parity in the Hispanic vote \u2014 a true political earthquake if it ever happened.", "In the long-ago days of the George W. Bush presidency there was a lot of talk from pro-immigration Republicans about how Hispanics were \u201cnatural Republicans\u201d \u2014 meaning family-oriented, religious, hardworking, in love with the American dream. But as the political parties were aligned in those days Hispanics fit pretty comfortably in the Democratic coalition. Even if they were more culturally conservative than white Democrats, they prioritized issues like health care and jobs and education and generally trusted the Democratic Party more on a range of domestic policy questions.", "The Republican elites who imagined that they could make inroads with Hispanics by passing a comprehensive immigration reform bill weren\u2019t completely out of touch, since there was often strong Hispanic support for that kind of measure. But the Republican Party\u2019s core obstacle was always economic policy. Bush\u2019s \u201ccompassionate conservatism\u201d probably helped him to a relatively strong showing with Hispanics in 2004, although one overstated by flawed exit polls (he probably got about 39 percent, not the oft-quoted 44 percent). But thereafter the party moved right on economics, and the sequence of Bush\u2019s push for Social Security privatization, the Tea Party\u2019s anti-spending zeal and then the Romney-Ryan ticket\u2019s promise of entitlement cuts all made the Republicans too economically libertarian to appeal to most Hispanics.", "Since then, though, three crucial things have changed. First, the shape of immigration is different: Both legal and illegal immigration have become less Latin American and more global, with a new pattern of rushes to the border by asylum-seekers who are more likely to come from Central America than Mexico. A simple story in which American Hispanics effectively saw themselves in every subsequent wave of migrants never quite fit reality, but for, say, a second-generation Mexican American in Texas it fits the reality of 2021 less than the reality of 15 years ago.", "As this shift was happening, the Democrats were moving leftward on most fronts, following public opinion at first (on same-sex marriage, for instance) but then arguably outpacing it. On economic policy, what counts as \u201ccentrism\u201d from Joe Manchin today would have placed him to the left of Barack Obama in 2010; on cultural and racial issues, the radicalization of white Democrats has moved them to the left of many Hispanic voters; on social issues, the kind of anti-abortion Democrat who once held the balance of power in the House of Representatives has mostly gone extinct.", "Then Trump\u2019s ascent in 2016 suspended the Republican commitment to austerity, entitlement cuts and other features of its Tea Party-era agenda. That didn\u2019t help Republicans make gains with Hispanics in 2016 because Trumpian bigotry was front and center \u2014 though keen observers noted that he did no worse than Romney in 2012.", "But the subsequent strength of the Trump economy, the sidelining of his party\u2019s deficit hawks and his administration\u2019s willingness to spend money in the face of the pandemic all created an opening for Republicans to cast themselves as pro-capitalism moderates and to portray the leftward-moving, Bernie Sanders-influenced Democrats as socialists. That frame was effective \u2014 the apparent potency of the \u201csocialism\u201d charge is discussed in the Equis Research report \u2014 and much more to the G.O.P.\u2019s advantage than a clash between stringent government cutters and moderate-welfare-state liberals, which was how the parties often appeared in the Obama era.", "Its emerging opportunity with Hispanic voters, then, crystallizes the larger Republican Party opportunity right now \u2014 where it\u2019s clear enough that a party that was genuinely moderate on economics, Trumpishly populist without being Trumpishly toxic, could lay claim to a lot of swing voters, and all without making the sweeping moves leftward on issues like immigration that were urged on Republicans 10 or 15 years ago.", "The question, as always, is how much of the party\u2019s core of donors and activists and voters wants to be economically moderate or wants to be nontoxic; I still think the answer is \u201cnot enough.\u201d", "The Democrats\u2019 Hispanic challenge likewise distills their larger political problem: How to recreate some version of their early Obama-era messaging, which presented a moderate liberalism that appealed more effectively to working-class voters of all races, in a very different social and economic landscape, in a party with a much more powerful and demanding progressive wing.", "One way or another that adaptation will be fraught and painful. But this is the moment when the Democrats need to do it \u2014 when the Hispanic realignment is still more hypothetical than real, still more visible in issue surveys than electoral results, still only a harbinger of an epic political defeat rather than the thing itself."]
